questions.text:
A 1-day-old newborn presents with respiratory distress. A chest X-ray is performed and is given below.



Based on the findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Answer: A. Congenital Diaphragmatic Hernia (Bochdalek type)

Explanation:

The given chest x-ray shows loops of bowel in the right thoracic cavity, mediastinal shift to the left, and decreased right lung aeration, which is consistent with Congenital Diaphragmatic Hernia.

Congenital Diaphragmatic Hernia (CDH):

  1. CDH is the intrathoracic herniation of abdominal contents due to congenital defects in the diaphragm.
  2. Types of CDH:
    • Bochdalek Hernia: Occurs through the posterolateral pleuroperitoneal canal, most commonly on the left side.
    • Morgagni Hernia: Anterior hernia located at the right cardiophrenic angle.

Fig. Schematic representation of CDH

  1. Radiologic Features:
    • Chest Radiograph (CXR):
      • Bochdalek hernia: Dome-shaped soft tissue opacity in the posterolateral thorax, often left-sided.
      • May show gas-filled bowel loops or fat content in the thoracic cavity.
      • Mediastinal shift away from the herniation due to mass effect.
      • On the lateral view, hernias appear above the posterior costophrenic recess.
    • CT/MRI:
      • Visualizes herniation of fat, bowel, spleen, or kidney through a diaphragmatic defect.
      • Important for distinguishing from other masses like cystic adenomatoid malformation or pericardial cyst.
      • CT provides clearer differentiation of soft-tissue or fatty mass protruding through the diaphragm.
  2. Complications:
    • Associated with hypoplasia of the ipsilateral lung, leading to respiratory distress, especially in neonates.
    • Neonates may present with respiratory distress and mediastinal deviation.

 

Esophageal atresia with tracheoesophageal fistula (Option B):

  • The primary abnormality may show air in the esophagus or stomach (if a fistula is present) and sometimes an absence of gas in the abdomen if there is no fistula.
  • This condition doesn't present with bowel loops in the thorax or a large diaphragmatic defect.

 

Pulmonary sequestration (Option C):

  • It presents as a mass in the lower lobe of the lung, often with an abnormal vascular supply seen on advanced imaging like CT angiography.
  • No bowel loops or significant mediastinal shift would be seen.

 

Congenital pulmonary airway malformation (CPAM) (Option D) appears as cystic masses within the lung, but the cysts are within the lung parenchyma, not abdominal contents in the thorax.

questions.text: A term neonate presents with failure to pass meconium within the first 48 hours of life. Imaging shows a narrow distal bowel segment with proximal colonic dilatation. The Barium Enema image of the neonate is given below. What is the most likely condition affecting this neonate?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Hirschsprung disease

 

Explanation:

Hirschsprung disease: Characterized by aganglionosis of the distal colon, typically presenting in neonates with failure to pass meconium. Radiographic findings show a narrow aganglionic segment with proximal dilatation.

 

Hirschsprung Disease

  • Hirschsprung disease is characterized by the absence of ganglion cells (aganglionosis) in the distal colon and rectum.
  • This condition may result from a failure of neural crest neuroblasts to migrate into bowel segments or the degeneration of already migrated neuroblasts. It impacts both the myenteric and submucosal plexuses.
  • Hirschsprung disease typically presents in term neonates with failure to pass meconium within 1-2 days after birth. About 75% of cases present within the first 6 weeks, and over 90% present by age 5, though rare adult cases occur.
  • In delayed cases with constipation, manometry can help differentiate short/ultrashort segment Hirschsprung from other causes.
  • Definitive diagnosis is made via full-thickness rectal biopsy (taken 2 cm above the dentate line).

Radiologic Findings for Hirschsprung Disease:

  • Plain Radiograph:
    • Findings resemble bowel obstruction with a smaller caliber affected bowel and varying degrees of colonic distension.
    • Severe cases may lead to dilatation, enterocolitis, and perforation.
  • Fluoroscopy (Contrast Enema):
    • Essential for diagnosis and determining bowel involvement.
    • Shows a narrow aganglionic segment with proximal dilatation and a saw-tooth pattern.
    • Delayed evacuation of contrast and the transition zone is depicted but not accurate for ganglion cell presence.
  • Ultrasound:
    • Can reveal fetal colonic dilatation in some cases.


Toxic Megacolon (Option B ruled out):

  • Acute complication associated with inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) and less commonly with infectious colitis and other colitides; characterized by severe colonic dilatation and risk of perforation due to loss of neurogenic tone.
  • Patients typically present with systemic illness and diarrhea.
  • Most commonly caused by ulcerative colitis.
  • Other causes include Crohn's disease, C. difficile colitis, neutropenic colitis, ischemic colitis, radiation-induced colitis, colonic lymphoma, graft-versus-host disease, and hypothyroidism (myxedema megacolon).
  • Hirschsprung disease can cause toxic megacolon in infants.
  • Radiographic Features:
    • Plain Radiograph: Transverse colon dilated to at least 6 cm (3-6-9 rule); signs of pneumoperitoneum may indicate perforation.
    • CT Scan: Shows loss of haustral markings, pseudopolyps, thumbprinting, and pericolic fat stranding due to mucosal edema.
    • Barium studies and colonoscopy are contraindicated due to perforation risk.

 

Crohn's disease (Option C): A chronic inflammatory bowel disease that can affect any gastrointestinal tract area. It usually presents in older children and adults with abdominal pain and diarrhea, not typically causing meconium passage issues in neonates.

 

Ulcerative colitis (Option D): Primarily affects the colon, leading to symptoms like bloody diarrhea and abdominal pain. It generally occurs in older children and adults and does not present with the specific failure to pass meconium seen in Hirschsprung disease.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with abdominal pain, weight loss, and chronic diarrhea. Radiologic studies reveal skip lesions in the ileum and cecum with a cobblestone appearance and deep ulcers. Which of the following radiologic signs is most consistent with this patient's diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) String sign of Kantor

 

Explanation:

  • The clinical scenario describes skip lesions, cobblestone appearance, and asymmetric mural thickening with deep ulcers, which are hallmark features of Crohn’s disease.
  • The string sign of Kantor is seen in Crohn’s disease and refers to the beaded, string-like appearance of the bowel due to multifocal narrowing from strictures.

 

Crohn’s Disease

Ulcerative Colitis
  • Skip lesions; ileum and caecum involved; rectum relatively spared.
  • Transmural; leads to ulceration, fissures, abscesses.
  • Bowel wall may be affected asymmetrically with sacculations.
  • Continuous colonic involvement; rectal in 95% of cases.
  • Mucosal and submucosal; less severe.
  • Fissure and abscess are not common.
  • Circumferential bowel wall symmetry is usually maintained.

1. Fluoroscopy (Barium Studies)

  • Mucosal abnormalities: Thickened, nodular folds and a "cobblestone" pattern due to a combination of longitudinal and transverse ulcers.
  • Aphthous ulcers: Appear as areas of barium collection within the swollen mucosa.
  • Shows deep ulcers, fistulae (e.g., enteroenteric, enterocolonic), and sinus tracts.
  • Chronic disease features: Strictures, stenosis, and wall sacculations.
  • String sign of Kantor: A beaded string-like appearance due to multifocal bowel narrowing from strictures.

2. Ultrasonography

  • Concentric mural thickening of the bowel wall.
  • Hyperemia within the inflamed segments.
  • Increased echogenicity of surrounding fat.

3. CT and MRI Enterography

  • Asymmetric Mural thickening
  • Ulcerations: Seen as air or contrast extending into the bowel wall.
  • Strictures
  • Mesenteric changes:
    • Comb sign: Engorgement of the vasa recta.
    • Mesenteric fat stranding, edema, and reactive adenopathy.
  • MRI-specific findings:
    • T2 hyperintense signal: Indicates mural edema, best seen with fat-saturated sequences.
    • Diffusion restriction: Suggestive of active inflammation.
    • Active inflammation shows hyperenhancement in arterial and post-contrast phases.

1. Radiographs

  • Bowel perforation and toxic megacolon: Radiographs (upright and supine) help screen for these conditions.
    • Toxic megacolon: Detected by colonic distension >6 cm, typically in the transverse colon.

Fig. Toxic megacolon in Ulcerative colitis

 
  • Other findings: Air-fluid levels, loss of colonic haustrations, mucosal islands, and absence of formed stool.
 

2. Fluoroscopy (Barium Enema)

  • Mucosal abnormalities: Granular and stippled mucosa, with superficial erosions and ulcers.
    • Collar button ulcers: Deeper ulcers extending into the submucosa. (Option B ruled out)
    • Pseudopolyps
  • Chronic disease features:
    • Lead pipe colon: Luminal narrowing and loss of haustrations in the colon. (Option A & C ruled out)
    • Patulous ileocecal valve (IC valve): With granular terminal ileum, indicative of backwash ileitis.

3. CT and MRI Enterography

  • Active phase:
    • Mural hyperenhancement:
    • Concentric mural thickening with stratification.
    • Submucosal edema: Seen as T2 hyperintensity on MRI.
    • Pseudopolyps
  • Chronic phase:
    • Lead pipe colon: Concentric mural thickening with luminal narrowing and loss of haustrations.
    • Submucosal fat deposition
    • Presacral space widening due to perirectal fat.
    • Post Inflammatory pseudopolyps

Comb Sign in active Crohn’s disease

Leadpipe appearance in Ulcerative colitis

String sign of Kantor and rectovaginal fistula

Inflammatory Pseudopolyps

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents to the emergency department with chronic abdominal pain, fever, and unintentional weight loss over the past month. He reports altered bowel habits and has a history of exposure to individuals with tuberculosis. A small bowel follow-through imaging is provided below. Based on the clinical presentation and the attached imaging, which of the following features is not typically seen in the patient?

choices.text: Spasm and edema at the ileocecal valve
Uniform thickening of the entire colon
Stierlin Sign with rapid barium emptying

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Uniform thickening of the entire colon

 

Explanation:

  • The patient's features including chronic abdominal pain, fever, and weight loss, with a history of exposure to tuberculosis and the small bowel follow-through image showing a circumferential mass effect at the ileocecal valve are characteristic of ileocecal tuberculosis.
  • In ileocecal tuberculosis, there is typically localized thickening (circumferential) rather than uniform thickening of the entire colon.

 

Ileocecal Tuberculosis:

  • Tubercular bacilli enter the GI tract via infected sputum or milk, leading to mucosal invasion and formation of tubercles in lymphoid tissue.
  • The ileocecal region is most commonly affected due to its abundant lymphoid tissue, with isolated colonic involvement in about 10% of cases, particularly in immunocompromised individuals.
  • Symptoms include chronic abdominal pain, fever, weight loss, and altered bowel habits.
  • Common complications are bowel obstruction and perforation.
  • Differential Diagnosis includes Crohn’s disease, lymphoma, amoebiasis, and cecal malignancy.

 

Imaging Features of Ileocecal Tuberculosis:

  • Radiographs: May show enteroliths, bowel obstruction with air-fluid levels, and signs of pneumoperitoneum in cases of perforation.
  • Small bowel follow-through:
    • Spasm and edema at the ileocecal valve and terminal ileum, leading to thickening and ulceration. (Option A)
    • Stierlin Sign: Rapid barium emptying in inflamed segments with normal barium column in adjacent segments. (Option D)
    • Features like hypersegmentation (chicken intestine), flocculation, and precipitation may be seen.
    • The inflammation and involvement of the cecum can lead to structural changes, resulting in retraction or elevation of the cecum, which is known as “Pulled up cecum”

  • Contrast-enhanced CT:
    • Circumferential thickening of the terminal ileum and cecum and asymmetric thickening of the ileocecal valve.
    • Pathognomonic associated mesenteric adenopathy (Option C) with characteristic central low attenuation due to caseous necrosis.
    • Chronic stages may present multifocal strictures and diffuse narrowing, with signs like the Fleischner or inverted umbrella sign (thickened ileocecal valve lips with narrowed terminal ileum).

questions.text: A 60-year-old female presents to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain, bloating, and vomiting. On examination, her abdomen is distended, and bowel sounds are decreased. A radiograph abdomen  of the patient is given below. Which of the following is not a feature of the patient’s condition?

choices.text: Arises in the pelvis, specifically the left lower quadrant

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Maintains a colonic haustral pattern

 

Explanation:

  • Sigmoid volvulus is characterized by a twisting of the sigmoid colon, leading to obstruction of the distal large bowel and resulting in a distended abdomen.
  • The "coffee-bean sign" is an X-ray feature that shows a distended sigmoid loop with an inverted U shape, indicative of the condition.
  • Sigmoid volvulus typically has an ahaustral appearance, whereas maintaining a colonic haustral pattern is a feature of cecal volvulus.

 

Sigmoid Volvulus

Caecal Volvulus
  • Sigmoid volvulus arises in the pelvis, specifically the left lower quadrant. (Option A ruled out)
  • It extends towards the right upper quadrant.
  • It has an ahaustral appearance (lack of haustra).
  • Causes obstruction of the distal large bowel, leading to dilation of the ascending, transverse, and descending colon.
  • A few gas-fluid levels may be seen.
  • Coffee-Bean Sign: The condition is characterized by a distended sigmoid loop with an inverted U shape, known as the coffee-bean sign (or kidney bean sign). (Option D ruled out)
  • Whirlpool Sign: The whirl, or whirlpool sign is observed when the bowel rotates around its mesentery, resulting in whirls of the mesenteric vessels. (Option C ruled out)
  • The torsion is located in the ascending colon above the ileocecal valve.
  • Caecal volvulus arises in the right lower quadrant.
  • It extends towards the epigastrium or left upper quadrant.
  • The colonic haustral pattern is maintained.
  • The distal colon is usually collapsed, and the small bowel is distended.
  • One gas-fluid level may be seen.
  • Definitive Sign: Upward displacement of the appendix and obstruction of the large bowel is a definitive sign of cecal volvulus.
  • May show a U-shaped distended bowel segment and signs of ischemia, including mural thickening, infiltration of the mesenteric fat, and pneumatosis intestinalis.
  • Whirlpool Sign: A whirl sign may be apparent due to tight torsion of the mesentery from a twist between the afferent and efferent loops.
  • Coffee Bean Appearance: A "coffee bean" appearance may be seen in a loop of transverse colon.
  • Bird's Beak Sign: Abrupt cut-off with “bird's beak” tapering at the distal cecum is characteristic.
  • Central appendix sign: Abnormal appendix position near midline.

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl with a known history of lymphoma is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of severe abdominal pain and intermittent vomiting. Her parents report that she has recently passed currant jelly stools. On physical examination, a palpable abdominal mass is noted in the right upper quadrant. An abdominal ultrasound is given below. Based on the clinical presentation and the ultrasound findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Intussusception

 

Explanation:

  • Intussusception occurs when one segment of the bowel telescopes into another, often due to a lead point, such as a lymphoma in this case.
  • The ultrasound findings showing a target sign are classic for intussusception.
  • The patient's symptoms of severe abdominal pain, vomiting, and currant jelly stools further support this diagnosis.

 

Intussusception

  • Intussusception occurs when one segment of the bowel is pulled into another, often leading to bowel obstruction and ischemia.
  • It is a common cause of acute abdomen in children, while in adults, it is typically associated with a focal lesion acting as a lead point.
  • The classic clinical presentation of intussusception in children may include intermittent abdominal pain, vomiting, and a palpable "sausage-like" mass in the right upper quadrant, although these symptoms occur in less than 20% of cases.
  • Parents may also report "currant jelly" stools, indicating bowel ischemia, and approximately 15% of patients may present without abdominal pain.
  • Plain Radiograph:
    • Elongated soft tissue mass in the upper right quadrant.
    • Bowel obstruction with air-fluid levels and proximal bowel dilation.
    • Possible absence of gas in the distal collapsed bowel.
  • Fluoroscopy:
    • Gold standard is the contrast enema, showing the intussusception as an occluding mass.
    • Characteristic "coiled spring sign."

Fig. Coiled spring sign

  • Ultrasound:
    • Target sign (doughnut sign)- Concentric alternating echogenic and hypoechoic bands are observed, where the echogenic bands represent the serosa and submucosa, flanking the hypoechoic muscularis propria.

  • Pseudokidney sign- Longitudinal ultrasound appearance of the intussuscepted segment of bowel which mimics a kidney

  • Crescent in a doughnut sign.
  • Absence of blood flow in the intussusceptum (contraindication for enema).
  • Features favoring ileocolic intussusception: hyperechoic core, thicker outer hypoechoic wall, larger anteroposterior diameter, and presence of lymph nodes.
  • CT Scan:
    • Characteristic "bowel-within-bowel" configuration.
    • Concentric rings of bowel on axial images, and sausage-shaped mass on longitudinal images.
    • Visualization of the lead point if present, with surrounding mesenteric fat and vessels.

 

Acute Appendicitis (Option A): Typically presents with right lower quadrant pain, nausea, and fever. It wouldn't show a target sign on imaging, and currant jelly stools are not associated with this condition.

 

Sigmoid Volvulus (Option C): Involves twisting of the sigmoid colon, presenting with abdominal distension and constipation. It would show a "coffee bean" sign rather than a target sign.

 

Cecal Volvulus (Option D): Similar to sigmoid volvulus, but involves the cecum. It typically shows signs of obstruction like “bird beak sign” but not the target sign on ultrasound.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain, vomiting, and a distended abdomen. On examination, his bowel sounds are diminished. An abdominal radiograph is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient based on the given findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Small bowel obstruction

 

Explanation:

Small bowel obstruction is characterized by the accumulation of gas and fluid in the intestine due to a blockage. The string of pearls sign, which appears as a row of small gas bubbles along the bowel wall, is virtually diagnostic of this condition, particularly in the context of the patient's symptoms.

 

String of Pearls Sign:

  • The string of pearls sign consists of a row of small gas bubbles in the abdomen, typically seen obliquely or horizontally.
  • These gas bubbles are trapped along the superior wall of the small bowel, between the valvulae conniventes.
  • The inferior margins of the bubbles have an ovoid appearance due to the meniscal effect of intraluminal fluid.
  • It can be observed on upright or decubitus abdominal radiographs and on CT scans.
  • Clinical Significance: When present in the appropriate clinical context, it is virtually diagnostic of small bowel obstruction.
  • Other Conditions: It may also be seen very rarely in adynamic ileus, acute gastroenteritis, and saline catharsis. (Options A, C & D ruled out)
  • Adynamic ileus:
    • Unlike a mechanical obstruction, where there is a physical blockage in the intestines, adynamic ileus results from impaired neural or muscular activity of the gut.
    • Abdominal X-rays or CT scans show diffuse bowel dilation without specific air-fluid levels or a transition point, which distinguishes ileus from mechanical bowel obstruction.
  • Fibromuscular Dysplasia (FMD): This non-atherosclerotic, non-inflammatory disease of blood vessels (often affecting renal or carotid arteries) produces alternating stenotic and aneurysmal segments, leading to a classic "string of beads" appearance on angiography.

Mesenteric ischemia (Option A): This condition presents with severe abdominal pain and distension due to reduced blood flow to the intestines. However, it usually does not show the characteristic air-fluid levels seen in small bowel obstruction and may include signs of ischemia.

 

Acute gastroenteritis (Option C): Unlikely, as it often presents with hyperactive bowel sounds, diarrhea, and cramping rather than the severe pain and diminished bowel sounds seen here.

 

Saline catharsis (Option D): Unlikely, as it typically causes loose stools and abdominal cramping but not severe abdominal pain or radiographic findings of distension.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old male presents with colicky abdominal pain, distension, vomiting, and absolute constipation for the past 48 hours. He has a history of prior abdominal surgery. On physical examination, his abdomen is distended with high-pitched bowel sounds. An abdominal X-ray is obtained and shows the following features.



What is the most likely diagnosis based on the clinical presentation and radiographic findings?
questions.solution:
Answer: A. Small bowel obstruction

Explanation:

  • This patient’s symptoms of colicky abdominal pain, vomiting, distension, and the presence of high-pitched bowel sounds are characteristic of a mechanical obstruction.
  • The radiographic findings show dilated loops of the bowel with valculae conniventes, suggestive of small  bowel obstruction.
  • The small bowel loops are identified by their location in the central abdomen and their smaller diameter (3–5 cm).
  • Additionally, the presence of previous abdominal surgery is a risk factor for adhesions, which are the most common cause of small bowel obstruction.

 

Differentiating Features Between Small Bowel and Large Bowel Obstruction:

Feature

Small Bowel

Large Bowel

Number of loops

Many loops visible

Few loops visible

Position of loops

Central abdomen

Peripheral (framing the small bowel)

Wall/Mucosal pattern

Valvulae conniventes (complete circular folds)

Haustra (incomplete bands)

Diameter

>3 cm

>6 cm (Caecum >9 cm)

Gas Pattern

Multiple air-fluid levels, "string of beads"

Distended colon, air-fluid levels
 

 

Large bowel obstruction (Option B): Typically shows more peripheral bowel dilatation, with larger loop diameters (usually >6 cm), and haustral folds that do not completely extend across the bowel lumen.

 

Sigmoid volvulus (Option C): This presents with the "coffee bean" sign on abdominal X-ray and is associated with large bowel obstruction, often seen in elderly patients. The absence of such a sign and the presence of small bowel dilatation make this unlikely.

 

Fig. Coffee bean with Coffee bean sign

 

Paralytic ileus (Option D): In paralytic ileus, the X-ray typically shows diffuse bowel dilatation without clear air-fluid levels. The high-pitched bowel sounds and specific dilated loops of the small bowel point toward a mechanical obstruction rather than a functional one.

questions.text:
A 1-day-old neonate presents with bilious vomiting and abdominal distension. An abdominal X-ray is performed and is given below.



Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Answer: C. Jejunal Atresia

Explanation:

Jejunal atresia is characterized by a "triple bubble" sign on an abdominal X-ray.

  • This appearance results from gas trapped in three distended proximal bowel loops: the stomach, duodenum, and proximal jejunum, with no distal gas beyond the atresia.
  • This condition is caused by intrauterine vascular insult leading to segmental bowel absence or occlusion.

 

Various Bubble signs of the abdomen:

Condition

Radiological Sign

Explanation

Normal Abdomen

Single bubble in the stomach

A single air bubble seen in the left upper quadrant corresponds to the fundus of the stomach. A large single bubble is seen in cases of pyloric atresia, GOO.

Pyloric Atresia (Option A)

"Single bubble" sign

A single distended stomach with no air in the small bowel or beyond, caused by obstruction at the pylorus.


 

Duodenal Atresia

(Option B)

"Double bubble" sign

Distended stomach and proximal duodenum; no distal bowel gas due to obstruction at the duodenum.

Jejunal Atresia

(Option C)

"Triple bubble" sign

Three distended loops of bowel (stomach, duodenum, proximal jejunum) with no distal gas.

Ileal Atresia

(Option D)

Multiple air-fluid levels

Dilated small bowel loops with air-fluid levels and no gas in the large intestine, more distal than jejunal atresia.

questions.text:
Match the following:


	
		
			
			
				Barium swallow
			
			
			
			a)
			
		
		
			2.Barium meal
			
			b)
			
		
		
			3.Barium follow through
			
			c)
			
		
		
			
			4.Barium enema
			
			
			d)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 1-c, 2-a, 3-d, 4-b

 

Explanation:

 

Barium Studies

Barium swallow

  • Test of the pharynx, esophagus, and proximal stomach
  • Contraindicated in any GI perforation- Esophageal or intestinal and Tracheo-esophageal fistula
  • There are three indentations in the esophagus :
  • 1st indentation- at the level of the Aortic Arch
  • 2nd indentation- at the level of Bronchus
  • 3rd indentation- at the level of the Left Atrium.

Barium meal

Tests the esophagus, stomach, and duodenum (the first part of the small intestine)

Barium follow through

  • Identify issues in the small intestine by tracking the passage of barium after ingestion.
  • After drinking a barium liquid, there is a 10-15 minute wait before X-rays are taken every 30 minutes until the barium reaches the large intestine.

Barium enema

  • Barium is given Transrectally.
  • Double-contrast (Barium + Air)
    • Positive contrast - Barium (white)
    • Negative contrast - Air (black)
  • Tests the pathologies of the large intestine- rectum, sigmoid colon and ascending, transverse and descending colon.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with intermittent dysphagia to solids but not liquids. A barium swallow study is performed, as shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis based on the radiological findings?
questions.solution:
Answer: A) Schatzki ring

Explanation:

The radiological finding shown is a thin, smooth, circumferential narrowing at the distal esophagus, which is characteristic of a Schatzki ring. It causes intermittent dysphagia and is often seen in older adults.

Esophageal Webs:

  • Thin shelf-like protrusion composed of submucosa and mucosa, covered by squamous epithelium, causing narrowing of the esophageal lumen.
  • Most commonly found on the anterior side of the proximal esophagus; can also be circumferential.
  • Types:
    • Congenital: Rare, due to failure in the coalescence of esophageal vacuoles during fetal development.
    • Acquired: More common, with multifactorial causes including associations with:
      • Plummer-Vinson syndrome (a triad of upper esophageal webs, iron deficiency anemia, dysphagia)
      • Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD)
      • Bullous dermatologic conditions
      • Graft-versus-host disease
  • Clinical Presentation: Dysphagia (difficulty swallowing), risk of food impactions, occasional aspiration, or very rarely, perforation.
  • Imaging Features:
    • On esophagography (barium swallow), webs appear as thin, fixed filling defects, most frequently in the anterior cervical esophagus or lower hypopharynx.

Fig. Cervical Esophagus Web


 

Esophageal Rings:

Types:

A Rings

B Rings

C Rings
  • Muscular rings formed due to hypertrophy of smooth muscle in the distal esophagus.
  • Covered in squamous epithelium.
  • Transient and result from active muscle contraction.
  • Asymptomatic and incidentally noted during esophagography.
  • Lower esophageal rings - fixed, mucosal rings located at the squamocolumnar junction.
  • Commonly found just above a hiatal hernia.
  • Symptomatic B rings - Schatzki Rings (diameter <13 mm) may cause dysphagia, especially when food passes through the narrowed area.
  • Located distal to the squamocolumnar junction.
  • Covered by squamous epithelium.
  • Least common and asymptomatic.
  • Represent diaphragmatic indentation of the esophagus

 

Imaging Features:

  • Best visualized on esophagography (barium swallow) with full barium distension of the esophagus.
  • A rings appear superior to B rings.
  • B rings present as concentric, fixed narrowing, seen during a barium swallow in the right anterior oblique position.

Fig. Esophageal rings

 

Plummer-Vinson syndrome (Option B):

  • It is associated with esophageal webs in the upper esophagus, not lower, along with iron deficiency anemia.
  • The barium swallow in this condition usually shows a web-like filling defect in the cervical esophagus rather than a ring at the gastroesophageal junction.

 

Diffuse esophageal spasm (Option C):

  • It is characterized by uncoordinated, simultaneous contractions of the esophagus.
  • On a barium swallow, this typically produces a "corkscrew" appearance rather than a circumferential ring-like narrowing.

 

Achalasia (Option D):

  • It involves failure of the lower esophageal sphincter to relax, leading to progressive dysphagia for both solids and liquids.
  • Radiologically, a barium swallow shows a "bird-beak" appearance in the distal esophagus and dilatation of the proximal esophagus.

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient presents with intermittent chest pain and dysphagia. A barium swallow study is performed as part of the diagnostic workup. Which of the following radiographic findings is most characteristic of diffuse esophageal spasm (DES) as shown in the image?

choices.text: Bird-beak appearance of the distal esophagus
Corkscrew or rosary bead appearance of the esophagus
Smooth, tapered narrowing of the mid-esophagus
Saccular outpouchings along the entire length of the esophagus

questions.solution:
Answer: B) Corkscrew or rosary bead appearance of the esophagus

Explanation:

  • The image shows corkscrew or rosary bead appearance of esophagus.
  • This appearance of the esophagus, although seen in less than 5% of cases, is a characteristic finding of diffuse esophageal spasm (DES) on barium swallow studies.

Diffuse esophageal spasm (DES)- Radiographic findings

Imaging Modality

Radiographic Findings

Description

Fluoroscopy (Barium Swallow)
  • "Corkscrew esophagus" or "rosary bead esophagus"
  • Non-peristaltic contractions pushing contrast in two directions
  • Normal appearance possible
  • 60% show abnormalities
  • <5% show "corkscrew esophagus"
  • Non-peristaltic contractions may be the only feature in some cases

CT
  • Circumferential wall thickening of the distal 5 cm of the esophagus
  • Seen in 20% of patients
  • Wall thickening ranges from 5 to 15 mm

 
  • Simultaneous contractions in the distal esophagus
  • Normal peristalsis interrupted by non-propulsive contractions
  • Gold standard for diagnosis
  • Not strictly a radiographic modality, but included for completeness

 

Manometry pressures of various motility disorders:

Esophageal Motility Disorder

LES Resting Pressure

LES Relaxation

Peristalsis

Contraction Amplitude

Normal

10-45 mmHg

Complete relaxation occur i.e ≤8 mmHg)

Coordinated peristalsis throughout

Normal amplitude is <180 mmHg

Achalasia

Elevated (>45 mmHg)

Incomplete relaxation (>8 mmHg)

Absent in the esophageal body

N/A

Diffuse Esophageal Spasm (DES)

Normal (≤45 mmHg)

Normal (≤8 mmHg)

Uncoordinated in >20% of swallows

Often high (>180 mmHg) in distal esophagus

Nutcracker Esophagus (Jackhammer Esophagus)

Normal (≤45 mmHg)

Normal (≤8 mmHg)

Normal

Very high (>220 mmHg)

Bird-beak appearance (Option A) is more characteristic of achalasia.

Smooth, tapered narrowing (Option C) is not typically associated with DES and might suggest a benign stricture.

Saccular outpouching along the entire esophagus (Option D) suggests diffuse esophageal diverticulosis. It is not a characteristic finding of DES, although some sacculations may be present.

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient presents with progressive dysphagia, initially for solids and later for liquids. A barium swallow study is performed, and two different radiographic findings are shown below. Which of the following statements correctly differentiates between these images?

choices.text: Image 1 shows achalasia cardia with a "bird beak" sign, while Image 2 shows carcinoma esophagus with irregular narrowing
Image 1 shows carcinoma esophagus with smooth narrowing, while Image 2 shows achalasia cardia
Both images show carcinoma esophagus affecting different parts of the esophagus

questions.solution:
Answer: A) Image 1 shows achalasia cardia with a "bird beak" sign, while Image 2 shows carcinoma esophagus with irregular narrowing

Explanation:
Image 1 clearly shows the characteristics of achalasia cardia:

  • Massively dilated esophagus with a narrow lower end
  • "Bird beak" sign due to the contraction of the lower esophageal sphincter
  • Smooth tapering at the distal end

Image 2 demonstrates features consistent with carcinoma esophagus:

  • Irregular narrowing of the esophagus
  • Malignant stricture in the mid-esophagus
  • Abrupt, irregular contour changes

Radiological findings in Achalasia cardia and Carcinoma Esophagus

Feature

Achalasia Cardia (Image 1) (Option C)

Carcinoma Esophagus (Image 2) (Option D)

Esophageal Appearance

Massively dilated esophagus

Irregular narrowing of esophagus

Distal Esophagus (Option B)

Narrow lower end ("bird beak" sign)

Malignant stricture

Location

Affects lower esophageal sphincter

Mid-esophagus in this case

Contour

Smooth tapering at distal end

Irregular, abrupt narrowing

Additional Features

Proximal esophagus is dilated

May show shouldering or "apple core" appearance (not visible in this image)


Fig. Apple core appearance

questions.text: A 72-year-old man presents with dysphagia, regurgitation, and halitosis. A barium swallow examination is performed which is given below. Which of the following radiological findings is most consistent with the presentation?

choices.text: An outpouching arising from the anterior wall of the proximal esophagus
Multiple small diverticula along the length of the esophagus
A diverticulum arising from the midline of the posterior wall of the distal pharynx
A smooth narrowing of the distal esophagus

questions.solution:
Answer: C) A diverticulum arising from the midline of the posterior wall of the distal pharynx

Explanation:
The radiological image shows a diverticulum arising from the midline of the posterior wall of the distal pharynx. This is the characteristic radiological finding of a Zenker's diverticulum on a barium swallow examination.

Zenker’s Diverticulum- Radiological findings

Imaging Modality

Key Findings

Barium Swallow (Fluoroscopy)
  • Diverticulum arising from the midline of the posterior wall of the distal pharynx
  • Located near the pharyngoesophageal junction
  • Best identified during swallowing
  • Best seen on lateral view
  • Typically noted at the C5-6 level
  • May be transient (referred to as a "pharyngeal pouch")

Additional Findings
  • ~90% of patients also show a hiatal hernia and gastro-esophageal reflux
  • The distended sac may compress the cervical esophagus

questions.text: A 58-year-old man presents to the emergency department with acute onset of severe abdominal pain and distension. An abdominal X-ray is performed, showing free air in the peritoneal cavity. Which of the following signs represents free air outlining the lateral umbilical ligaments?
questions.solution:
Answer: B) Inverted V sign

Explanation:

  • In cases of pneumoperitoneum, the radiological sign that is specifically associated with free air outlining the lateral umbilical ligaments is Inverted V sign.
  • The inverted "V" sign, also known as the lateral umbilical ligament sign, is a sign of pneumoperitoneum manifested by the visualization of an inverted "V" shape in the pelvis on supine view of abdominal radiographs.
  • It represents free gas outlining the lateral umbilical ligaments.
  • In infants, the lateral umbilical ligaments contain the umbilical arteries, while in adults, they contain the inferior epigastric vessels.

Pneumoperitoneum- Various signs seen on X-ray

Sign

Description

Decubitus abdomen sign

Free air between the abdominal wall and the liver on left lateral decubitus view

Ligament sign (Falciform ligament sign) (Option A)

Visualization of the falciform ligament due to free air on both sides

Inverted V sign

Air surrounding the lateral umbilical ligaments

Telltale sign (Triangle sign) (Option C)

Triangular accumulation of air between bowel loops

Doge cap sign (Option D)

Air in Morrison's/hepatorenal pouch

questions.text:
A 72-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of severe abdominal pain and distension. An upright chest X-ray is performed, showing the following finding:



Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis based on this radiographic finding?
questions.solution:
Answer: B) Pneumoperitoneum

Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation and radiological image indicate pneumoperitoneum, which can be identified by the classical Rigler sign seen in the given X-ray, also known as the double-wall sign, which is seen when gas is outlining both sides of the bowel wall, i.e. gas within the bowel's lumen and gas within the peritoneal cavity.
  • Pneumoperitoneum refers to the presence of free air in the peritoneal cavity, often indicating a perforated hollow viscus.
  • Another condition, referred to as pseudo-pneumoperitoneum, describes any low attenuation within the abdominal cavity that masquerades as free intraperitoneal gas or pneumoperitoneum.

Pseudo-pneumoperitoneum typically shows Chilaiditi sign which includes:

  • Colonic interposition
  • Presence of colonic loop between diaphragm and liver

Pneumoperitoneum- Radiological findings

Imaging Modality

Key Findings of Pneumoperitoneum

Upright Chest X-ray
  • Subdiaphragmatic free gas
  • Continuous diaphragm sign

Supine Abdominal X-ray
  • Rigler's sign (gas within the bowel's lumen and gas within the peritoneal cavity)
  • Cupola sign (air beneath the dome of diaphragm)
  • Football sign (oval-shaped collection of air in the upper abdomen)
  • Triangular air collection in Morrison's pouch

CT Scan
  • Free air in the peritoneal cavity
  • Air outlining intra-abdominal organs
  • Air trapped between bowel loops

Ultrasound
  • Enhanced peritoneal stripe sign
  • Shifting phenomenon (movement of air with patient positioning)

 

Rigler sign

Cupola sign

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents with sudden, severe abdominal pain and a rigid abdomen. He has a history of peptic ulcer disease. An erect chest X-ray is given below. Which of the following radiological signs is NOT expected in this case?

choices.text: Free gas under the right hemidiaphragm

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Chilaiditi sign

 

Explanation:

  • In this clinical scenario, the presence of free air under the right hemidiaphragm on an erect chest X-ray suggests pneumoperitoneum, which commonly indicates a perforated viscus, such as a peptic ulcer.
  • The cupola sign and Rigler’s sign further support the diagnosis, as they reveal free gas and an outline of the bowel wall.
  • Chilaiditi sign represents a pseudo-pneumoperitoneum where the intestine (usually colon) is interposed between the liver and diaphragm, mimicking free air but not representing true pneumoperitoneum. Therefore, it must not be present in this scenario.

Fig. Chailaiditi sign

 

Pneumoperitoneum

  • Pneumoperitoneum refers to the presence of free gas in the peritoneal cavity, typically indicating a perforated viscus (e.g., perforated peptic ulcer).
  • Causes:
    • Common: Perforated peptic ulcers, bowel obstruction, inflammatory conditions, ischemia, injury during colonoscopy.
    • Other causes without peritonitis: Postoperative (up to 7 days), peritoneal dialysis, sealed perforation, and tracking from pneumomediastinum.
  • Diagnosis on Imaging:
    • Erect CXR: Free gas seen under the right hemidiaphragm (cupola sign), difficult to differentiate on the left due to gastric or colonic gas. (Option A & C ruled out)
    • Supine AXR: Right upper quadrant gas in the perihepatic, subhepatic space, Morrison’s pouch, and ligament visualization (e.g., falciform ligament).
    • Rigler’s Sign: Visualization of both sides of the bowel wall due to surrounding gas. (Option B ruled out)
    • CT Scan: Most sensitive; small volumes of gas seen in the liver or peritoneal recesses, often using broad window settings.
  • Pseudo-pneumoperitoneum: Conditions mimicking free gas such as Chilaiditi syndrome (intestine between liver and diaphragm), subphrenic abscess, or subdiaphragmatic fat.
  • Pneumoperitoneum may be clinically silent, especially in elderly, steroid-treated, unconscious, or critically ill patients.

questions.text: A newborn is diagnosed with an anorectal malformation (imperforate anus) on physical examination. Given the high association with VACTERL anomalies, the medical team decides to conduct a series of radiographic studies to assess for potential associated conditions. Which of the following is a key imaging modality in the evaluation of a neonate with imperforate anus?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Invertogram

 

Explanation:

The invertogram is crucial for assessing the most distal level of the bowel in male patients with imperforate anus, particularly when meconium is present on the perineum without an apparent perineal fistula. Proper positioning is essential for accurate evaluation.

 

Invertogram

  • Used to classify anal atresia in neonates by visualizing the distance between the gas bubble in the terminal colon and the perineal skin.
  • Typically performed 24 hours after birth to allow for small fistulas to become apparent.
  • The newborn is inverted from the lower limbs, with careful positioning to avoid hip and shoulder rotation.
  • Remove any radiopaque items and ensure the X-ray is taken during full inspiration.
  • Can cause discomfort and crying, which may lead to misleading results; a prone cross-table lateral view can be a more comfortable alternative.

Invertogram image showing anal atresia

 

Plain abdominal X-ray (Option A): While useful for ruling out esophageal atresia and other anomalies, it does not provide specific information about the anatomy or level of the anorectal malformation.

 

Abdominal ultrasound (Option C): This is important for evaluating hydrocolpos and hydronephrosis in females with cloacal anomalies but does not assess the anorectal malformation itself.

 

Distal colostogram (Option D): This test can evaluate the distal bowel but is typically performed after a colostomy has been created, making it less relevant for initial assessment in a newborn with an imperforate anus.
